messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement Update
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-08-30T13:27:31Z
## Message ID: 20200830-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2020-08-30T10:55Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2020-08-28T15:26Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2020-08-30T10:55:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 19, 2020 - August 25, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-08-26T20:07:14Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-08-19T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-08-25T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200826-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There was 1 C-type CME (see details below). The C-type CME starting around 2020-08-16T18:24Z as seen on the SOHO LASCO C2 coronagraph mentioned in last week's report was not observed to arrive at Earth. 

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period. 

An interplanetary shock was observed by STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments at 2020-08-19T21:14Z, increasing the total magnetic field strength to 20 nT. This activity may be associated with the S-type CME starting around 2020-08-15T23:12Z as seen on the SOHO LASCO C2 coronagraph.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)                     
2020-08-22T16:36Z     ~549            C               -35/-11               9                           SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-08-26T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-09-01T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are currently no significant active regions on the solar surface as seen in the available imagery. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be between low and moderate levels due to a coronal hole high speed stream expected to arrive around 2020-08-28.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 12, 2020 - August 18, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-08-19T19:01:20Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-08-12T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-08-18T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200819-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There was 1 C-type CME (see details below). Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that this C-type CME starting around 2020-08-16T18:24Z may have a glancing blow at Parker Solar Probe at 2020-08-19T04:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20200817-AL-001). 

Based on additional heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that this C-type CME may also impact STEREO A and missions near Earth. For 48 ensemble members, simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach STEREO A between about 2020-08-19T04:12Z and 2020-08-19T06:26Z (average arrival 2020-08-19T05:05Z) for 16% of simulations, and also NASA missions near Earth between about 2020-08-19T10:55Z and 2020-08-20T00:51Z (average arrival 2020-08-19T18:30Z) for 100% of simulations. The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 79% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 2-4 range (below minor to below minor) (see notification 20200817-AL-002).

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=3 occurred during the synoptic period of 2020-08-18T21:00Z-24:00Z.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was briefly elevated above the threshold level of 1000 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period due to the high speed stream starting at 2020-08-02T04:30Z. This enhancement gradually subsided and returned to background levels by the end of the reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to minor this week due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt towards the beginning of the reporting period described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2020-08-16T18:24Z     ~541            C               -25/-8                29                          SOHO, STEREO A                    

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-08-19T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-08-25T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be at low to moderate levels for the upcoming week. There are a couple of small active regions currently visible on the solar surface as seen in the available imagery. Geomagnetic activity is expected to fluctuate between low and moderate levels with the arrival of a C-type CME (mentioned above) on or after 2020-08-19 and the influence of a diffuse coronal hole high speed stream on or after 2020-08-22.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (Parker Solar Probe, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-08-17T20:37:13Z
## Message ID: 20200817-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2020-08-16T18:24:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20200817-AL-001). Based on heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 48 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2020-08-19T04:12Z and 2020-08-19T06:26Z (average arrival 2020-08-19T05:05Z) for 16% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2020-08-19T10:55Z and 2020-08-20T00:51Z (average arrival 2020-08-19T18:30Z) for 100% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 79% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 2-4 range (below minor to below minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2020-08-17_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX071/20200816_182400_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX071_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2020-08-17_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX071/20200816_182400_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX071_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2020-08-17_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX071/20200816_182400_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX071_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2020-08-17_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX071/20200816_182400_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX071_probabilistic_Kp_forecast_wdist.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2020-08-17_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX071/20200816_182400_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX071_arrival_STA.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2020-08-17_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX071/20200816_182400_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX071_STA_stack.gif

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at SWRC is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2020-08-17_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX071/Detailed_results_20200816_182400_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX071.txt

###

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Parker Solar Probe, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-08-17T17:38:51Z
## Message ID: 20200817-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2020-08-16T18:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~541 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 29 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -25/-8 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2020-08-16T18:24:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Parker Solar Probe (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2020-08-19T04:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2020-08-19T22:32Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-4 (below minor).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2020-08-16T18:24:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20200817_002100_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20200817_002100_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20200817_002100_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20200817_002100_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20200817_002100_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20200817_002100_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20200817_002100_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20200817_002100_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20200817_002100_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20200817_002100_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_PSP_timeline.gif


## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 05, 2020 - August 11, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-08-13T00:38:24Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-08-05T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-08-11T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200813-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.        

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with the Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=2 for the reporting period. STEREO A IMPACT instrument detected potential CME arrival around 2020-08-05T13:30Z.  

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu starting at 2020-08-05T08:15Z and stayed elevated throughout the reporting period (see notifications 20200805-AL-001, 20200807-AL-001, 20200809-AL-001 and 20200811-AL-001). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with a coronal hole high speed stream starting on 2020-08-02.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-08-12T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-08-18T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. Several small active regions are currently visible on the solar surface as seen in the available imagery. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt remains slightly elevated although below the threshold of 1000 pfu after being elevated throughout the reporting period. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the diminishing enhancement of the electron flux above and a possible disturbance on or after 2020-08-14 due to the arrival of a minor diffuse coronal hole high speed stream.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-08-11T13:21:00Z
## Message ID: 20200811-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.
 
 
## Summary:
 
This is an update to the notifications with Activity ID 2020-08-05T08:15:00-RBE-001 (notifications 20200805-AL-001, 20200807-AL-001, and 20200809-AL-001).
 
Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu, initially crossing this threshold at 2020-08-05T08:15Z. The electron flux has continued to exceed this threshold and is currently elevated around 1400 pfu.
 
The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2020-08-02T04:30Z, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 750 km/s. The solar wind speed measured at L1 has since subsided and is currently measured to be around 300 km/s.
 
NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.
 
Activity ID: 2020-08-05T08:15:00-RBE-001.

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu, initially crossing this threshold at 2020-08-05T08:15Z. The electron flux has continued to be above this threshold or elevated, currently around 1600 pfu.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2020-08-02T04:30Z, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 750 km/s. The solar wind speed measured at L1 has since subsided and is currently measured to be around 340 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2020-08-05T08:15:00-RBE-001.

## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement Update

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux continues to rise above 1000 pfu, initially crossing this threshold at 2020-08-05T08:15Z (see notification 20200805-AL-001). The electron flux has most recently crossed this threshold at 2020-08-07T06:45Z.
 
The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream that started at 2020-08-02T04:30Z, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 750 km/s. The solar wind speed measured at L1 has since subsided and is currently measured to be around 450 km/s.
 
NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.
 
Activity ID: 2020-08-05T08:15:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 29, 2020 - August 04, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-08-05T21:35:23Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-07-29T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-08-04T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200805-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:
 
Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.    
 
Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with the Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2020-08-03T00:00Z-03:00Z and 2020-08-04T03:00Z-06:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2020-08-02.
 
The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was slightly enhanced above background levels on 2020-08-04 due to the arrival of the coronal hole high speed stream described above. However, the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period.
 
The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.
 
Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.
 
##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location        
None Observed
 
CMEs (>500 km/s):
 
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time) 
None Observed
 
Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time) 
None Observed
 
## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-08-05T00:00Z
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-08-11T23:59Z
 
The solar activity is expected to be at low levels for the upcoming week. There are three active regions currently visible on the solar surface as seen in the available imagery. A continual enhancement in the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES may be observed towards the beginning of the upcoming week. Currently, the integral electron flux is above the 1000 pfu threshold starting at 2020-08-05T08:15Z (see notification 20200805-AL-001). Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week with the possible arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream around 2020-08-06.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score
